resources.string: Fired when a Pomodoro has started.
Fired when a Pomodoro is about to end.
Fired when a Pomodoro has finished.
Fired when a Pomodoro break has started.
Fired when a Pomodoro break is about to end.
Fired when a Pomodoro break has finished.
Move the caret to the start of the edit box
To open the assistant, re-press the assistant button.
Launch assistant with a navigation shortcut
Play songs, playlists, albums, audiobooks, and podcasts
Make calls by name or number
Make calls by number or phoneword
Send text, images, and files to your apps
Add tasks to a todo.txt file
Set timers for work and breaks

The text you enter will be sent to a web browser for search. URLs are opened directly.
 
 If the text matches one of your bookmark keywords, the bookmark will be directly opened.
 
 If the text starts with one of your search engine keywords, that site will be searched for the rest of your query.
You\'ll be presented with a list of apps matching your search. An exact match or single result will launch immediately.
This command sends a simulated \'play\' key event, resuming an active audio player if there is one.\n \n In the future, you\'ll also be able to search for medias to play.
This command sends a simulated \'pause\' key event, pausing any persistent audio in the \"Music\" stream.
In the future, this command will search your device for filenames matching your input.

The person or number you enter will be called immediately. If no contact match is found, the text will be dialed as a phoneword—letters matched to numbers on a keypad. For now, you can save phone numbers by name in assistant settings. In the future, the command will search your system contacts with graphical selection.
 
 This command requires phone call permission.
 
 For non-immediate dialing, see the 'dial' command.

The text you enter will be sent to your dialer app. Most dialers convert non-numeric text to a phone number via the keypad-letter system. You can use this to search your contacts with T9 dialing!
 
 In the AOSP dialer for example, submitting "Dial Cameron" will include any contacts named Cameron in its search results for "226-3766".
 
 For immediate calls, see the 'call' command.

You can provide recipients in the command instruction. Multiple recipients may be separated with commas or ampersands. In the future, the word "and" will be usable.
 
 Recipients can be contacts or phone numbers. For now, you can save phone numbers by name in assistant settings. In the future, the command will search your system contacts with graphical selection.
 
 You can type a message in the data field. This may overwrite an existing SMS draft!
 
 You can provide a subject line using the "subject field" button. For now, this doesn't seem to work..

This command has three actions: view, edit, and create.
 
 In view, you're presented with a list of contacts matching your input. You can select one to view its details.
 
 In edit, you select a contact to edit it.
 
 The create action launches your device's "new contact" dialog. You can provide details before and after submission.

You can provide recipients as the command's instruction. Multiple recipients may be separated by commas or ampersands. In the future, the word "and" will be usable.
 
 You can add CC or BCC recipients using their respective keywords, after which all contacts listed will be in that category until another category is given. In the future, these will be separate fields.
 
 Recipients can be contacts or email addresses. For now, you can save emails by name in assistant settings. In the future, the command will search your system contacts with graphical selection.
 
 In the future, you'll be able to provide a subject line.
 
 You can type a message body in the data field.
 
 You can provide files with the 'attach' button and pictures & videos with the 'media' button.
The text you enter will be sent to your maps app for search. In the future, you\'ll be able to save locations and search contact addresses.

The text you enter will be evaluated as a math expression.\n \n In the future, more functions will be supported and you\'ll be able to use natural language like \"plus\" and "times" in the instruction.

To get a random number, provide a range. A single number will yield a pseudorandom number from 1 to that number, inclusive.
 
 Giving two numbers will yield a value between them, inclusive. You may separate them with 'and', '&', or commas if you'd like.
 
 You can also use explicit range notation, where []s indicate inclusivity and ()s indicate exclusivity.
 
 If no range is given, the default is [-(2^32), 2^32).

To roll dice, provide a dice notation expression.
 
 Example: roll 1d6 + 2d8.
 
 If no instruction is given, a simple coin flip will occur.

Enter numbers with bitwise operators to get a result.
 
 Valid operators are <<, >>, >>>, &, ^, |, and ~.
 
 The arithmetic operators +, -, *, /, and % also work. Note that / performs integer (floor) division and % performs remainder (modulo) division.
 
 Precedence is as follows: NOT and negation, multiplicatives, additives, bit-shifts, AND, XOR, then OR.
 
 This command performs integer arithmetic with 64-bit signed integers.
Simply opens your weather app.\n \n Not all weather apps are detected yet. In the future, this will be mitigated.

Tells the local time.
 
 In the future, you'll be able to give a time zone or location to tell the time from.
 
 In the future, you'll be able to tell what time it was some duration ago or the time will be after a certain duration has passed.

You can set alarm time and repeating weekdays in the command instruction.
 
 For time, minutes and the colon are optional. You can abbreviate AM and PM as 'a' and 'p'. If AM/PM isn't specified, either 24-hour time or the soonest occurrence of the time label will be used depending on locale and system preferences.
 
 Example valid times: 10:30 PM, 4:00a, 1120, 159AM, 2p.
 
 For weekdays, you can use their names—full or abbreviated separated by spaces—or a simple string in the form "UMTWRFS". Order and capitalization never matter.
 
 You can label the alarm in the data field.

You can set timer duration in the command instruction.
 
 If the duration is just a number, that will be the length in minutes. Duration can be given as HH:MM or HH:MM:SS. It can also be given as numbers and time units in any order. Time units can be abbreviated and decimal values may be used.
 
 Example valid durations: 3.5, 2:30, 1.5 hrs 10 min, 2 minutes, 1h2m7s, 4:30:27.
 
 Duration can also be given as an until-time. Start your instruction with "until", "till", or "til" and provide a clock time and the timer will go off at that time. This follows the same time formatting rules as the 'alarm' command except seconds are also allowed.
 
 You can label the timer in the data field.
You can set the note file in the command instruction or with the \'attach\' button.\n \n You can provide note text in the data field. Otherwise, the file will be opened in an editor as normal.

The details you enter will be sent to your calendar app. You can label the event in the command instruction. You can also set the date and time.
 
 To do so, separate the event title with the pipe '|' character and provide DATE @ TIME, which can also be separated by the words 'at' and 'from'
 
 For now, date is formatted as a month name, day number, and/or year in any order. Months may be abbreviated. Whole years can be given, or the shorthand 'YY with the apostrophe will default to the current century.
 
 'Tomorrow' is also a valid date. In the future, more shorthands such as weekdays will be supported.
 
 The time can be just the start time or START-END. The words 'until', 'till', 'til', and 'to' can also be used to split start and end time. Times can include seconds, see the 'alarm' command for format instructions.
 
 In the future, these will all be separate fields. Example command: Calendar Tennis match | tomorrow from 3 to 5.
 
 You can add a location or URL to your event by using their respective field-toggle buttons. In the future, more details such as confidentiality and repetition pattern will be supported.
 
 You can use /allday to make it a whole-day event, where time-of-day info is ignored. In the future, this will be a toggle button.
You can set a notification title with the instruction. You can set notification text in the data field.
This command opens your settings app. In the future, you\'ll be able to save and set specific settings at will.
The text you enter will be copied to your clipboard.\n \n Pressing the submit button a second time with the same text will close the assistant and get it out of your way.

Snippet text will be copied to your clipboard. You can specify a snippet by name in the instruction.
 
 To create a snippet, name it with the instruction and provide text in the data field.
 
 To remove a snippet, use the 'remove' subcommand.
 
 To copy and remove a snippet, use the 'pop' subcommand.
 
 Pressing the submit button a second time with the same text will close the assistant and get it out of your way.

The text you enter will be sent to your device's 'share' dialog. In the future, you'll be able to use the command instruction to search for a specific app.
 
 You can provide text in the data field.
 
 You can provide files with the 'attach' button and pictures & videos with the 'media' button.
 
 Some apps don't support multi-line text.
Submitting this command toggles your device\'s flashlight.\n \n For now, it takes no input. In the future, you\'ll be able to give a strobing pattern.

This opens an app\'s \"App info\" page. If no input is given, Emilla\'s will open.\n \n Otherwise, you\'ll be presented with a list of apps matching your search. An exact match or single result will be opened immediately.
You\'ll be presented with a list of apps matching your search. The uninstall prompt will show immediately for an exact match or single result.
The text you enter will be shown in a short pop-up message. The command instruction and data field will be line-separated if applicable.\n \n More than 2 lines of text are usually ellipsized.
The text you enter will be appended to a todo.txt file.\n \n You can write multiple tasks in the data field.

You can specify a minute duration in the command instruction. You can make it a break by including 'break' or 'b'.
 
 If you don't specify a duration, the default work is 25 minutes and the default break is 5.
 
 In the future, a gentler notification will be used.
You\'ll be prompted to select a command, after which you can proceed with instruction as normal. In the future, the dialog won\'t immediately submit the command.
The app will be launched by this command.

The text you enter will go to the app's 'share' function.
 
 In the future, some apps will let you specify recipients in the command instruction.
 
 In the future, you'll be able to add file attachments for apps that support them.
 
 Submitting without instruction will launch the app normally.

The text you enter will go to the app's 'share' function.
 
 For now, the command instruction and data field will be line-separated when applicable. In the future, some apps will let you specify recipients in the instruction.
 
 In the future, you'll be able to add file attachments for apps that support them.
 
 Submitting without instruction will launch the app normally.
The text you enter will go to the app\'s search function.\n \n Submitting without instruction will launch the app normally.

Your instruction will search for a task to run. An exact match will run immediately.
 
 Any lines in the data field will be sent as parameters. To have multiple lines in a parameter, put a '\' character at the end of the line. To have backslashes, double them '\\'.
 
 To simply show a list of tasks, use the 'list'/'run' subcommand with no further search terms.
 
 Tasker's Misc > Allow External Access setting is required.
\"%1$s\" doesn\'t appear to be a phone contact, but you can call it as \"%2$s\".
\"%1$s\" doesn\'t appear to be phone contacts, but you can message \"%2$s\".
\"%s\" doesn\'t appear to be a contact, but you can make one.
You can\'t span more than 2 times.
The contact doesn\'t have a phone number.
No apps can perform this action.
Snippet \"%s\" doesn\'t exist, but you can make it with the data field.
You don\'t have any saved snippets.
Your device doesn\'t support phone calls.
Your device doesn\'t support SMS messaging.
Sorry! I don\'t know how to modify specific settings yet.
Sorry! I don\'t know how to write notes yet.
Sorry! This command doesn\'t support your Android version yet.
Sorry! I don\'t know how to search through contacts yet.
Sorry! I don\'t know how to search for files yet.
Sorry! I don\'t have categorical app search yet.
Sorry! I can\'t label the timer without a duration.
Sorry! No locations or elapse-time yet, working on it.
Unfinished feature! The idea is to copy a file when text isn\'t provided.
External access isn\'t enabled in Tasker.
Tasker receive tasks. This is probably a Tasker bug.
Permission is denied, but you can allow it in settings.
Permission is needed to read device contacts.
